This page attempts to dispel **common assumptions and misconceptions** that many players may have about [NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack").

- [4 Attributes](#Attributes)
  - [4.1 Gauntlets of power are required to maximize carrying capacity](#Gauntlets_of_power_are_required_to_maximize_carrying_capacity)

## Nutrition

### Drinking water is necessary

The [Guidebook](/wiki/Guidebook "Guidebook")'s advice on this matter is misleading, stating that "although creatures can survive long periods of time without food, there is a physiological need for water". Though that is true for real life, [it surely does not apply for the game](/wiki/NetHack_is_not_real_life "NetHack is not real life"), where there is absolutely no need to drink water at all — instead of being healthy, [quaffing](/wiki/Quaffing "Quaffing") from [fountains](/wiki/Fountain "Fountain") can be downright dangerous.

### Because corpses are dangerous to eat, they should be saved for emergencies

[Some corpses](/wiki/Corpse#Corpses_that_are_both_beneficial_and_harmful "Corpse") are, indeed, inherently dangerous and should not be eaten. Any other corpse should be eaten while it is still fresh, if you plan to eat it at all. If you save a corpse to eat later, it will almost certainly be [tainted](/wiki/Corpse#Aging "Corpse") and give you [food poisoning](/wiki/Food_poisoning "Food poisoning"). [Lizard](/wiki/Lizard "Lizard") and [lichen](/wiki/Lichen "Lichen") corpses are exceptions to this rule, as they last indefinitely.

### I would not eat that in real life, so my character also probably should not

Remember: [NetHack is not real life](/wiki/NetHack_is_not_real_life "NetHack is not real life"). Though most of us would not eat a [sewer rat](/wiki/Sewer_rat "Sewer rat") or a (uncooked!) [jackal](/wiki/Jackal "Jackal")'s corpse, and would most probably get ill if we did, that is not an issue for your character in the game. Therefore, if a corpse is fresh, unless there is something intrinsically harmful about the monster that dropped it—such as the [kobold](/wiki/Kobold "Kobold"), which is poisonous, or the [cockatrice](/wiki/Cockatrice "Cockatrice"), which causes [stoning](/wiki/Stoning "Stoning")—it will probably be safe for consuming.

### Eating pet corpses is bad

There is no specific penalty for eating a [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet")'s [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") after the creature is already dead, but there are several similar things that do have bad effects:

- Personally killing the pet incurs a penalty of -15 alignment and -1 [Luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck").
- Eating the corpse or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") of a domestic [cat](/wiki/Cat_or_other_feline "Cat or other feline") or [dog](/wiki/Dog_or_other_canine "Dog or other canine") will give you the [aggravate monster](/wiki/Aggravate_monster "Aggravate monster") intrinsic, but this applies regardless of whether it was a pet.
- [Sacrificing pets](/wiki/Sacrifice#Sacrificing_pets "Sacrifice") that have died while tame also gives bad effects including the aggravate monster intrinsic, and should be avoided.

## Magic

### Wizards are better at reading spellbooks

In fact, the formula that determines the chance of successfully reading a [spellbook](/wiki/Spellbook "Spellbook") is the same for all roles (and, just for completeness, all races and alignments). The only advantage [Wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") have in reading books is that, when attempting to read an [uncursed](/wiki/Uncursed "Uncursed") book with less than 100% chance of success, they are given a warning and prompted whether to continue reading. The actual success chance, however, is the same as for all other roles. Rather, Wizards are better at *writing* [unknown scrolls and spellbooks](/wiki/Magic_marker#Unknown_scrolls_and_spellbooks "Magic marker") than other roles.

### The player should not wear metal armor if intending to cast

Metal does tend to hinder casting, but some types of metallic armor have much less effect than many players may think. For example, a Wizard with 18 [intelligence](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") can wear a metal helmet, boots, or gloves and can still cast low-level spells with 0% failure, and will only see a small increase in fail rate for higher-level spells. [Shields](/wiki/Shield "Shield") and metallic [body armor](/wiki/Body_armor "Body armor") interfere with casting the most.

## Behavior

### A chaotic character can kill anything without penalties of any kind

Actually, characters of chaotic [alignment](/wiki/Alignment "Alignment") get alignment and Luck penalties for most of the same things that characters of other alignments do, such as killing coaligned peaceful monsters or [killing always-peaceful humans](/wiki/Murder "Murder"). See the [alignment record](/wiki/Alignment_record "Alignment record") article for more details on alignment penalties and bonuses.

### Offering a human corpse is bad

**If you are playing as a non-chaotic human, this is generally true.** That said, there is no specific penalty (or bonus, for that matter) for the [sacrifice](/wiki/Sacrifice "Sacrifice") of human corpses - it's [sacrificing one's own race](/wiki/Sacrifice#Sacrificing_creatures_of_own_race "Sacrifice") that is a special case, and which is almost always a bad idea for non-chaotic adventurers.

## Attributes

### Gauntlets of power are required to maximize carrying capacity

[Carrying capacity](/wiki/Carrying_capacity "Carrying capacity") is based on more than just [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength"), and also has a limit. Specifically, the formula is (([Str](/wiki/Strength "Strength") + [Con](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution")) \* 25) + 50, with the result capped at 1000. Therefore, if (Str + Con) >= 38, carry capacity is maxed, and all races other than elf can reach this without [gauntlets of power](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_power "Gauntlets of power") or any other additional equipment.
